The meeting of the Children, Young People and Education Committee discussed the Welsh Government's childcare offer, which provides 30 hours of free childcare for 3-4 year olds from low-income families. The Minister for Children and Social Care, Huw Irranca-Davies, reported that the early implementer local authority areas have had a mixed experience with the rollout, with some areas finding it challenging due to bureaucracy and administrative burdens. The Minister acknowledged that the offer has been well-received by parents, particularly those from disadvantaged backgrounds, who are seeing benefits such as increased disposable income and more flexibility to balance work and childcare.

The committee raised several concerns, including the potential to exacerbate disadvantage for summer-born children who only receive 3 terms of the offer, and the lack of awareness among parents about the UK tax-free childcare offer. The Minister and officials acknowledged these concerns and committed to improving communication and integration with the UK Government's offer.

The committee also discussed the quality of childcare, with a focus on ensuring that providers are meeting the required standards. The Minister mentioned that the Welsh Government is working to increase the qualifications of childcare staff and improve the quality of childcare.

The meeting concluded with the committee resolving to meet in private for the remainder of the meeting.
